Subject: Here we go
Content:
Dear all,

 

I’m back at it. 

 

I had a newsletter in the last millennium and fortunately no one will ever be able to unearth those bits of juvenilia. Quite reassuring. (Snowden, if you unearth these ramblings, get at me.)

 

For twelve years, I edited the Scout Report at the University of Wisconsin, which remains a great way to learn about compelling websites of interest to scholars, librarians, and Poindexters of all persuasions. That work ended in 2014 and after a long breather it left like time to return to sending out an occasional missive about my work and things that I hope you’ll enjoy. 

 

Here it is, this week’s flotsam and jetsam.

 


The Wrong Type of Blues

 

A few years back, the Chicago Department of Transportation started to add bits and pieces of street furniture-cum-public art to a number of streets. Lawrence Avenue in Chicago’s Ravenswood/Lincoln Square neighborhood got a clutch of blue chairs that missed the mark. Here's my missive on this misguided bit of peacemaking. 

 

 

 What We Talk About When We Talk About the Early Days of the World Wide Web

 

From time to time, I teach a class called “Cyberspace and Society” (I didn’t  pick the name, and yeah, I know: “cyberspace”) and I’ve made some deep dives on the Internet Archive to look around and see what I can use to keep students engaged.

One of my more compelling finds was the TV show “Net Cafe”, which ran from 1996 to 2002. They are aaaa—mmaaaaa—zzziiing (said in the voice of Carl Sagan)

 

You can watch Nicholas Negroponte talk about technology, learn about the perils (or attractions?) of online voyeurism, and so on. 

 

 

 New York, I Love Your Creative Time

 

Since 1973, the non-profit arts group Creative Time has continued to push the envelope with a raft of public art projects in curious corners of New York and those that are rather well-known, including Times Square and Rockefeller Center. If you don’t know their work, take a look. And if you do, still take a look. They are always up to something new.

 

Free Walks and Talks on Chicago’s Culinary History By Yours Truly

 

Throughout the entire year, I’m giving walks and talks on Chicago’s culinary history as part of the Chicago Public Library’s “One Book, “One Chicago” program.

 

This Tuesday (11/1), meet me at the Water Works branch (yup, it’s right off the Mag Mile) at 6PM for my walk based on the book “Vittles and Vice” by Patricia Bronte. We’ll get to see a few historic restaurants and talk about the transformation of Chicago’s dining scene in the past few decades.

 

Be well and rants, raves, or miscellany are always welcome at maxgrinnell@gmail.com. 

 

Max
